Number

Number ç±»å‹

  • â€ uses the IEEEâ€“754 format to represent both integers æ•´æ•° and floating-point values æµ®ç‚¹å€¼ (also called doubleâ€“precision values åŒç²¾åº¦å€¼ in some languages) â€ Page 17

Number Literal Formats

  • â€ Integers â€ Page 17
  • â€ octal literal â€ Page 17
    • â€ the first digit must be a zero (0) followed by a sequence of octal digits (numbers 0 through 7). â€ Page 17
    • â€ Octal literals are invalid when running in strict mode â€ Page 17
  • â€ hexadecimal literal â€ Page 17
    • â€ must make the first two characters 0x (case insensitive), followed by any number of hexadecimal digits (0 through 9, and A through F) â€ Page 17
    • â€ Numbers created using octal or hexadecimal format are treated as decimal numbers in all arithmetic operations. â€ Page 17

â€ Floating-Point Values â€ Page 17

  • To define a floating-point value, you must include a decimal point and at least one number after the decimal point. Page 17
  • ECMAScript always looks for ways to convert values into integers. Page 18
  • e-notation ç§‘å­¦è®¡æ•°æ³• Page 18
    • used to indicate a number that should be multiplied by 10 raised to a given power Page 18
      • let floatNum = 3.125e7; // equal to 31250000
      • 3eâ€“17 Page 18
        • 0.00000000000000003 Page 18
    • ECMAScript converts any floating-point value with at least six zeros after the decimal point into e-notation Page 18
  • small rounding errors Page 18

â€ Range of Values â€ Page 18

  • Number å±æ€§
    • Number.MIN_VALUE Page 18
      • 5 eâ€“324 Page 18
    • Number.MAX_VALUE Page 18
      • 1.7976931348623157 e+308 Page 18
    • Number.POSITIVE _ INFINITY Page 19
      • Infinity (positive infinity) Page 18
        • Infinity: 23 / 0
        • any positive number that canâ€™t be represented Page 18
        • If a calculation returns either positive or negative Infinity, that value cannot be used in any further calculations Page 19
    • Number.NEGATIVE _ INFINITY Page 19
      • â€“Infinity (negative infinity) Page 18
        • Any negative number that canâ€™t be represented Page 18
  • BigInt(ES2020)
    • The biggest number: 2 ** 53 - 1
    • Only 53 bits are used in JS to store the digits; the rest are used to store decimals
    • Numbers are represented as 64 bits

â€ NaN â€ Page 19

  • not a number
  • any operation involving NaN always returns NaN Page 19
  • NaN is not equal to any value, including NaN Page 19
  • isNaN() function Page 19
    • to determine if the value is â€œnot a number.â€ Page 19
    • Any value that cannot be converted into a number causes the function to return true. Page 19

â€ Number Conversions â€ Page 20

  • â€ Number() function è½¬å‹å‡½æ•°â€ Page 20

  • unary plus operator Page 21

    • works the same as the Number () function. Page 21

Number å¯¹è±¡å®ä¾‹æ–¹æ³• Page 17

  • toString() Page 17
    • å‚æ•°
      • å¯é€‰åœ°æ¥æ”¶ä¸€ä¸ªè¡¨ç¤ºåŸºæ•°çš„å‚æ•°
    • è¿”å›å€¼
      • å¹¶è¿”å›ç›¸åº”åŸºæ•°å½¢å¼çš„æ•°å€¼å­—ç¬¦ä¸²
  • toFixed() Page 18
    • can represent numbers with 0 through 20 decimal places Page 18
  • toExponential() Page 18
  • toPrecision() Page 18
    • can represent numbers with 1 through 21 decimal places Page 19

Number æ„é€ å‡½æ•°æ–¹æ³•

  • â€ parseInt() â€ Page 21

    • å‚æ•°

      • â€ If this first character isnâ€™t a number, the minus sign, or the plus sign, parseInt() always returns NaN â€ Page 21
      • â€ parseInt() provides a second argument: the radix åŸºæ•° (number of digits). â€ Page 21

    • è¿”å›å€¼

      • é»˜è®¤ä¸ºåè¿›åˆ¶æ•°å€¼
      • â€ itâ€™s advisable to always include a radix to avoid errors. â€ Page 22

    • ç”¨æ³•

  • â€ parseFloat() â€ Page 22

    • â€ a decimal point is valid the first time it appears, but a second decimal point is invalid and the rest of the string is ignored â€ Page 22

  • isFinite() function Page 19

    • To determine if a value is finite (that is, it occurs between the minimum and the maximum) Page 19

  • Number.isInteger()

    • Check if a value is Interger

  • Number.isSafeInteger() Page 19

    • Number.MIN_SAFE_INTEGER, or -2^53 + 1 Page 19
    • Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER, or 2^53 - 1 Page 19
